page.title: 16HAMPTON WATERWORKS
page.content: The Waterworks{came to Hampton}in the{middle of the nineteenth century because of the amount of pollution in the Thames. Dumped sewage was causing epidemics of typhoid and cholera. Although the current took the waste out to sea the tide brought it all back in. {The taking of water from the {Thames below Teddington Weir was {prohibited in 1852. In 1854 three London water companies transferred to Hampton. They were the {Grand junction Waterworks,}the {Southwark and Vauxhall Waterworks}and the{Middlesex Waterworks.} The site was ideal for the land was flat, little used and conveniently close to London for pumping. {All three {buildings still stand today.
